items.title: Edward I. Koch, a Mayor as Brash, Shrewd and Colorful as the City He Led, Dies at 88
items.abstract: Mr. Koch, a showman of City Hall, was a three-term mayor who steered New York City through the fiscal austerity of the late 1970s and the racial conflicts of the 1980s.

items.title: 36 Hours in Panama City Beach, Fla.
items.abstract: Peer beyond the tattoo parlors and sweaty spring breakers and you’ll find everything from sugary sands to a farmers’ market in this Emerald Coast town.

items.title: Scientists Propose a New Architecture for Sustainable Development
items.abstract: Analysts of global environmental trends seek to topple the three pillars of sustainable development.

items.title: A Missionary’s Quest to Remake Motor City
items.abstract: Against tall odds, Dan Gilbert, the Quicken Loans chairman, is putting down money to revive a two-square-mile area that was once Detroit’s core.

items.title: London Festival Celebrates Role of Design in L'Herbier's Films
items.abstract: The movie-maker of the 1920s and 1930s wanted to showcase modernist styles of design in the world of cinema.

items.title: Bitter Debate Over Nuclear Power Simmers in Rural South Korea
items.abstract: In 2010, three villages agreed to give up their land to make room for a power plant, plunging the area into a battle over whether the plant would be a savior or a death knell.

items.title: Wesley A. Clark, Who Designed First Personal Computer, Dies at 88
items.abstract: Mr. Clark’s designs built a bridge from the era of mainframe systems that were programmed with stacks of punch cards to personal computers that respond interactively to a user.

items.title: Review: Pacific Northwest Ballet Plays With Limits and Dystopia at City Center
items.abstract: Pacific Northwest Ballet delivered two New York premieres on Friday, David Dawson’s “A Million Kisses to My Skin” and Crystal Pite’s “Emergence.”

items.title: Toxic Moss in Portland, Ore., Shakes City’s Green Ideals
items.abstract: When a study found toxic materials on tree trunks in residential neighborhoods of Portland, it produced an upheaval of surprise, anger and fear.

items.title: For $10, New York City Students See ‘Hamilton’ and Rap for Lin-Manuel Miranda
items.abstract: Students in a program sponsored by the Rockefeller Foundation rapped and sang for this show’s creator, Lin-Manuel Miranda, before attending the show.

items.title: How Bauhaus Redefined What Design Could Do for Society
items.abstract: A century after its founding, the German school of art and architecture remains one of the most transcendent — and frustrating — movements of the Modernist age.

items.title: Review: The More, Further (Final?) ‘Tales of the City’
items.abstract: Netflix gives Armistead Maupin’s modern-day fable of San Francisco lives and lifestyles a fourth go-round.

items.title: In Chicago’s Vibrant Theater Scene, Two Tales of One City
items.abstract: A huge new literary adaptation and a tiny old melodrama both find a place in a healthy cultural ecosystem.

items.title: Comics That Capture the City in All Its Human and Physical Messiness
items.abstract: In her Graphic Content column, Hillary Chute looks at new works from Mark Alan Stamaty and Jaime Hernandez that each grapple with urban existence.

items.title: Austerity Has Ravaged U.K. Communities. It Has Also Spurred Reinvention.
items.abstract: As local governments across Britain grapple with shrunken budgets, many are going into business, funding cooperatives and speculating in real estate.

items.title: Could Detroit Become the Next Fashion City?
items.abstract: In bringing an exhibition of creative talent to New York, the fashion label Deviate wants to show that Detroit has more to offer than a quick hit of novelty for luxury giants.

items.title: Celebrating Black History Month? These 5 Cities Are Going All Out
items.abstract: Honoring all things African-American, with performances, river cruises, exhibitions and more, in Richmond, Va., Portland, Ore., Philadelphia, Cleveland and San Antonio.

items.title: A Classic Paris Apartment Filled With Outré Design
items.abstract: With his thoughtfully arranged collection of Joe Colombo furniture and minimalist art, an exhibition producer has made an appealingly unexpected home for himself.

items.title: She Never Stopped Loving Otis Redding. Her City Never Stopped Needing Him.
items.abstract: The soul singer has been gone for more than half a century. Zelma Redding’s love affair with him — and his with Macon, Ga. — has never ended.

items.title: What to Do in New York City in June
items.abstract: Looking for something to do in New York? See Sam Jay record her latest comedy special in Brooklyn, or watch as dancers get nearly naked for a good cause.
